comments:
Build ID: unknown

Steps To Reproduce:
1. In the STEM Designer view, start the New Disease wizard (New -> New Disease)
2. Assign a name, fill in all parameter fields, click 'next', then 'finish'
3. Watch it come up with an error message in the Error Log tab


More information:
Occasionally, I get this exception when I start the wizard:
Message: Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: "org.eclipse.core.resources".
Exception: org.eclipse.swt.SWTException: Invalid thread access
(Off to a great start - but it is not something that happens every time.) This doesn't crash the wizard, though.

The exception that I can reproduce by taking the steps above is this one:
Message: org.eclipse.ohf.stem.ui (i.e. STEM doesn't really have suggestions as to what happened)
Exception: java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException

This happens when running STEM off the jarfile, not from inside Eclipse

I just tried this on a Windows machine and couldn't reproduce it.  It could be a linux issue. Having the entire stack trace would be helpful.  Also, what was the name you used?

John, can you reproduce this on linux?

(In reply to comment #1)

Name, I'm not sure what you mean. On the various occasions I filled in 'sgpdisease' for Name and 'Spanish Flu' or 'Obscure Fever' (did I mention this was meant to be a test run???) for Disease Name in the form. The parameters were mostly done at random (typically between 0.01 and 0.5, though), especially after the first few crashes. The only one I never touched was the non-linearity coefficient. As for the model, I think I mostly chose SEIR, but not always.

Ok, good, thanks this is helpful.  

Does this always happen or just occasionally?

The method  NewIdentifiableWizard.createIdentifiable() appears to be throwing an exception when it is trying to add the Identifiable instance created by the wizard to a ResourceImpl.  This was outside of the try clause to catch such exceptions.  I've moved the code into the try clause and added another catch to catch all Exceptions and log them.  This isn't a fix yet, but it should help to determine what is causing the problem.

The code is committed.

Well... I checked out the code on a different machine (also Linux) that's not behind our Firewall of Death(TM) and...it works. No exception, no warnings, nothing. So I don't know what else to tell you except that if you want to declare this WORKSFORME then by all means, go ahead...

Very strange. There is some exception being thrown and then caught higher up in Eclipse and converted to a "general" InnvocationException. If you're motivated, you might try the new code on the old machine and see what happens.  The real exception should be logged.

I like to kill bugs dead, and I don't know what was really happening with this one so I'm going to keep it open for now. Thx.

But why would I get an index-out-of-bounds here and not on the other machine?

I don't know if it's relevant, but the Java versions on the two computers are slightly different. The one where it works has 1.5.0_03, the one where it doesn't uses 1.5.0_07. Other than that, I don't know.

The array index value is being extracted from the combo box that displays the disease models for the user to select.  Index 0 is set as the selected disease model when the combo box is created.  For some reason, the combobox.getSelectionIndex() is returning -1, which I think is returned when nothing has been selected....need to investigate.

I could reproduce the Exception by clearing the combobox used to select the disease model and clicking on "Finish".  I got exactly the same exception.  I then changed the construction of the combobox to be SWT.READ_ONLY so that it can't be cleared.  I was unable to clear the combobox (no surprise) and could not reproduce the exception.  Could you try it on the machine where it is failing please.

Thx, 
Dan

The exception still occurs.

I'm giving up on this. Exporting Stem from Eclipse is tricky to say the least, and it's got too many other teething troubles apart from this particular bug. So we've decided not to use it.

If you want to keep tracking it go ahead but I won't be available to test things. Besides, I'm beginning to think it was something I did wrong, not something that was wrong with the programming. So I'd put this one on hold until/unless someone else runs into the same problem.

--Nicoletta
There could be some Linux difference with how the combo box is handled.  A more concrete fix will be to force the index value to be non-negative.  I'll do that when I return.

(In reply to comment #12)
> There could be some Linux difference with how the combo box is handled.  A more
> concrete fix will be to force the index value to be non-negative.  I'll do that
> when I return.
> 
I tried it on my Linux box and could not reproduce the problem with the latest code.  I even  added a println for the combo.getselectionindex and it was always 0 1 or 2

I suspect the bug is fixed.  It would be pretty weird for the combo box to be returning -1 after I made it read only.  One explanation is that the code was not updated from the repository after the fix was committed.  I'm going to mark it as fixed.
